title: What Does It Mean If a Bird Hits Your Window? Spiritual Interpretations

steps.title: A new change is flying your way.
steps.content: A new change is flying your way. This change might be big and noticeable, like an upcoming move to a new apartment or a fun date with someone you met online. The change in question could also be something that’s low-key but still significant, like going on a spontaneous day trip over the weekend or taking a big trip to the grocery store. [1] X Research source Change can be a little stressful, but it doesn’t have to be! Lighten your load by looking at life through a more humor-filled lens. [2] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Business Review Online and print journal covering topics related to business management practices Go to source

steps.title: Luck is in your future.
steps.content: Luck is in your future. Ironically and sadly enough, some people believe that a bird that dies upon the impact of a collision is actually symbolic of good luck. By this logic, the bird’s tragic sacrifice offers something positive in its wake. [3] X Research source At the end of the day, being “lucky” or “unlucky” is completely out of your control. The best ways to feel in control of your life are through healthy habits like exercising , breathing deeply , and practicing self-reflection . [4] X Trustworthy Source Greater Good Magazine Journal published by UC Berkeley's Greater Good Science Center, which uses scientific research to promote happier living Go to source

steps.title: Good things are on the horizon.
steps.content: Good things are on the horizon. Maybe your life has felt pretty unlucky lately, or you just don’t see anything fun or interesting in your future. A bird flying into your window can be a powerful symbol that good, positive energy is headed in your direction—you just have to be trusting and faithful. Keep yourself in a healthy headspace by practicing plenty of healthy habits , like transforming negative thoughts into positive ones. [5] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source

steps.title: It’s time to trust your gut.
steps.content: It’s time to trust your gut. Your intuition is a force to be reckoned with—and if you’re seeing a bird fly into your window, it could be a sign that you aren’t quite listening to it enough. Pay attention to what conversation you're having. Pay attention to what you had on your mind. Take a moment to check in with yourself and see how you’re feeling; if something seems “off,” take a deeper dive into that feeling to figure out what’s going on. See what type of energy your body is giving off before making a decision. If you’re feeling tight and tense about something, it could be a sign to step back from whatever is stressing you out. If you’re feeling more open and spirited, it could be a sign to approach a situation with open arms. [6] X Research source

steps.title: It’s time to make small but meaningful changes.
steps.content: It’s time to make small but meaningful changes. It’s easy to feel like your life is going in circles sometimes, especially if you do the same thing day after day. Instead of doing the same thing over and over and hoping that the results will be different, look for small but significant adjustments you can make that’ll send you in a new direction. [7] X Research source Brainstorm a list of small changes you might make to your daily routine. If you’d like to be healthier, for instance, but don’t want to go to the gym, you might cut back on electronics time and replace it with a walk around the neighborhood.

steps.title: An angel or spiritual guide is trying to get in touch with you.
steps.content: An angel or spiritual guide is trying to get in touch with you. If a bird just hit the window, there’s a chance that an angel or other spiritual power put it there. Maybe it’s a message of support or a sign that you need to be on your guard—whatever the case, make sure that you’re tuned in! According to many spiritual circles, angels send messages through angel numbers, or special repeating lines of numbers that pop up in your daily life. [8] X Research source Check out wikiHow’s “ What Is My Angel Number? ” quiz to see what angel number could be significant in your life.

steps.title: It’s time to keep an eye on your finances.
steps.content: It’s time to keep an eye on your finances. Some people believe that a bird hitting the window can be a sign that you’re stressing out a little too much about your finances. Other people believe the opposite—that the bird is a sign that you need to work hard to reach a sense of financial stability and comfort. Small habits can make a big difference when it comes to your financial security, like setting a budget and saving your money properly.

steps.title: Something in your life is coming to an end.
steps.content: Something in your life is coming to an end. A bird hitting your window doesn’t mean that someone in your life is doomed—instead, it means that something in your life could be reaching its conclusion, like a job or relationship. [9] X Research source Take courage in the fact that, at the end of the day, you decide what becomes of your life.

steps.title: Sparrow
steps.content: Sparrow Sparrows often symbolize a sense of emotional healing—but at times, they might even have a romantic connotation for your life. [10] X Research source If one of these birds slams into your window, an emotional or romantic awakening could be in your future.

steps.title: Dove
steps.content: Dove From a historical standpoint, doves are greatly symbolic of harmony and peace. [11] X Research source With this in mind, a dove flying into your window may be a hopeful sign of peace and hope for the days and weeks to come.

steps.title: Hummingbird
steps.content: Hummingbird Hummingbird superstitions tend to revolve around the condition of the hummingbird after it slams into your window. If it survives the collision, good luck is apparently in your future; if it dies, bad luck could be on the horizon. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Eagle
steps.content: Eagle Okay, it’s pretty unlikely that a bald eagle is going to slam into your kitchen window—but if it does, it could be symbolic of your sense of freedom (or lack thereof). Since eagles are symbolic bastions of independence, an eagle-window collision might mean that you’re feeling cornered in some aspect of your life. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Birds mistake the reflections in windows for nearby scenery.
steps.content: Birds mistake the reflections in windows for nearby scenery. Oftentimes, windows and sliding glass doors reflect images of the scenery nearby, as well as the glare of the sun. These cues make the bird think that they’re flying in the correct direction when they’re actually headed toward a solid wall of glass. [14] X Trustworthy Source The Cornell Lab of Ornithology Research lab of Cornell University dedicated to interpreting and conserving the Earth's biological diversity through research and education about birds Go to source Birds might also mistake their reflection for a different bird that’s invading their territory, and try to go after it. Reflections from nighttime lights can also trick birds to fly into the glass.

steps.title: Birds sometimes get intoxicated after snacking on fermented fruit.
steps.content: Birds sometimes get intoxicated after snacking on fermented fruit. After fruit falls off its growing plant and sits on the ground, it starts to ferment (the chemical process that turns sugar into alcohol). When birds eat this fruit, they get a little tipsy. [15] X Research source Eating fermented fruit can intersect with other contributing factors, like the glare of sunlight off the glass and/or a misleading reflection. All in all, this can contribute to a very untimely collision for the bird.

steps.title: Place the bird in an aerated cardboard box or paper bag.
steps.content: Place the bird in an aerated cardboard box or paper bag. Using a clean towel, carefully lift the bird and set it down in a sturdy and breathable compartment, like a cardboard box with holes poked into it. [16] X Trustworthy Source The Humane Society of the United States National organization devoted to the promotion of animal welfare Go to source The bird is likely dead if its legs aren’t moving at all. [17] X Trustworthy Source National Audubon Society Nonprofit environmental organization focused on conservation, citizen science, and public science education Go to source If the bird is dead, slip on a mask and a pair of disposable gloves before transferring it to a plastic bag and tossing it out. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Leave the bird in a dark and peaceful spot.
steps.content: Leave the bird in a dark and peaceful spot. Find a shady but warm place so the bird can rest and recover without being disturbed. Try to find a place where there won’t be any disturbances from nearby kids or pets. [19] X Trustworthy Source The Humane Society of the United States National organization devoted to the promotion of animal welfare Go to source Make sure you set the bird down in an open spot, so it can easily fly away whenever it wants.

steps.title: Wait at least 30 minutes and see if the bird is ready to fly.
steps.content: Wait at least 30 minutes and see if the bird is ready to fly. Once every half hour, peek in at the bird and see how it’s doing. If it seems to be getting its bearings, carry the box or bag to an open space and let the bird fly free. [20] X Trustworthy Source The Humane Society of the United States National organization devoted to the promotion of animal welfare Go to source Make sure that you aren’t touching the bird at all when you’re checking in on it.

steps.title: Call a local wildlife rehabilitator for help if the bird is alive but immobile.
steps.content: Call a local wildlife rehabilitator for help if the bird is alive but immobile. Even if you have the best intentions, wildlife injuries require special care and medical intervention that untrained individuals just can’t provide. Let the rehabilitator know what happened, as well as where they can pick up the bird. [21] X Trustworthy Source The Cornell Lab of Ornithology Research lab of Cornell University dedicated to interpreting and conserving the Earth's biological diversity through research and education about birds Go to source Click here to find a wildlife rehabilitator in your area.

steps.title: Bird-proof your windows to prevent any future incidents.
steps.content: Bird-proof your windows to prevent any future incidents . To protect your birds from any more collisions, move your bird feeder so it’s either less than 3 ft (0.91 m) or more than 30 ft (9.1 m) away from the window—the bird won’t take as much damage if it flies from a really close or really far distance. [22] X Research source You can also make manual adjustments, like: Installing a window screen in front of your window Applying unique soap patterns to the windows Spacing any wind chimes and/or decals so they’re very close together Creating a chart of tape on the glass [23] X Trustworthy Source The Humane Society of the United States National organization devoted to the promotion of animal welfare Go to source
